Examples

Comprehensive code examples to get you started with AutoFaker

Basic Usage Examples

Built-in Types

Generate anonymous data for Python's built-in types:

basic_types.py 
from autofaker import Autodata
import datetime

# Built-in types
text = Autodata.create(str)
number = Autodata.create(int)
decimal = Autodata.create(float)
complex_num = Autodata.create(complex)
byte_data = Autodata.create(bytes)
range_obj = Autodata.create(range)

# DateTime types
now = Autodata.create(datetime.datetime)
today = Autodata.create(datetime.date)

print(f"String: {text}")
print(f"Integer: {number}")
print(f"Float: {decimal}")
print(f"DateTime: {now}")
print(f"Date: {today}")

# Output might be:
# String: f91954f1-96df-463f-a427-665c99213395
# Integer: 2066712686
# Float: 725758222.8712853
# DateTime: 2017-06-19 02:40:41.000084
# Date: 2019-11-10

Simple Classes

Create instances of custom classes with anonymous data:

simple_classes.py 
from autofaker import Autodata

class Product:
    def __init__(self):
        self.id = 0
        self.name = ""
        self.price = 0.0
        self.in_stock = True

class Order:
    def __init__(self):
        self.order_id = 0
        self.customer_name = ""
        self.items = []
        self.total = 0.0

# Create single instances
product = Autodata.create(Product)
order = Autodata.create(Order)

print(f"Product: {product.id}, {product.name}, ${product.price}")
print(f"Order: {order.order_id}, {order.customer_name}, ${order.total}")

# Create multiple instances
products = Autodata.create_many(Product, 5)
print(f"Created {len(products)} products")

DataClasses

Work with Python dataclasses for cleaner code:

dataclasses_example.py 
from dataclasses import dataclass
from autofaker import Autodata
from datetime import datetime

@dataclass
class User:
    id: int
    username: str
    email: str
    created_at: datetime
    is_active: bool

@dataclass
class BlogPost:
    id: int
    title: str
    content: str
    author: User  # Nested dataclass
    published: bool

# Create a user
user = Autodata.create(User)
print(f"User: {user.username} ({user.email})")

# Create a blog post with nested user
post = Autodata.create(BlogPost)
print(f"Post: {post.title}")
print(f"Author: {post.author.username}")

Decorator Examples

@autodata with Type Arguments

Use the decorator with explicit type arguments:

decorator_args.py 
import unittest
from autofaker import autodata

class Calculator:
    def add(self, a: int, b: int) -> int:
        return a + b
    
    def multiply(self, a: float, b: float) -> float:
        return a * b

class TestCalculator(unittest.TestCase):
    
    @autodata(Calculator, int, int)
    def test_add_integers(self, calc, num1, num2):
        result = calc.add(num1, num2)
        self.assertEqual(result, num1 + num2)
        self.assertIsInstance(result, int)
    
    @autodata(Calculator, float, float)
    def test_multiply_floats(self, calc, num1, num2):
        result = calc.multiply(num1, num2)
        self.assertAlmostEqual(result, num1 * num2, places=5)
        self.assertIsInstance(result, float)

# Run the tests
if __name__ == '__main__':
    unittest.main()

@autodata with Type Annotations

Cleaner syntax using Python type annotations:

decorator_annotations.py 
import unittest
from autofaker import autodata
from dataclasses import dataclass
from typing import List

@dataclass
class Customer:
    id: int
    name: str
    email: str

@dataclass
class Order:
    id: int
    customer: Customer
    items: List[str]
    total: float

class OrderService:
    def calculate_discount(self, order: Order) -> float:
        if order.total > 100:
            return order.total * 0.1
        return 0.0

class TestOrderService(unittest.TestCase):
    
    @autodata()
    def test_calculate_discount_high_value(self, 
                                         service: OrderService,
                                         order: Order):
        # Manually set total to test discount logic
        order.total = 150.0
        discount = service.calculate_discount(order)
        self.assertEqual(discount, 15.0)
    
    @autodata()
    def test_calculate_discount_low_value(self,
                                        service: OrderService,
                                        order: Order):
        order.total = 50.0
        discount = service.calculate_discount(order)
        self.assertEqual(discount, 0.0)

@fakedata Decorator

Generate realistic fake data for testing:

fakedata_decorator.py 
import unittest
from autofaker import fakedata
from dataclasses import dataclass

@dataclass
class Employee:
    id: int
    first_name: str
    last_name: str
    email: str
    job: str
    company: str

class EmployeeValidator:
    def validate_email(self, employee: Employee) -> bool:
        return "@" in employee.email and "." in employee.email
    
    def validate_name(self, employee: Employee) -> bool:
        return len(employee.first_name) > 0 and len(employee.last_name) > 0

class TestEmployeeValidator(unittest.TestCase):
    
    @fakedata()
    def test_email_validation(self, 
                            validator: EmployeeValidator,
                            employee: Employee):
        # employee will have realistic data like:
        # first_name: "John", last_name: "Smith", 
        # email: "john.smith@example.com", job: "Software Engineer"
        
        is_valid = validator.validate_email(employee)
        self.assertTrue(is_valid)
        print(f"Testing email: {employee.email}")
    
    @fakedata()
    def test_name_validation(self,
                           validator: EmployeeValidator, 
                           employee: Employee):
        is_valid = validator.validate_name(employee)
        self.assertTrue(is_valid)
        print(f"Testing name: {employee.first_name} {employee.last_name}")

Fake Data Examples

Comprehensive Fake Data

Generate realistic data for various field types:

comprehensive_fake.py 
from dataclasses import dataclass
from autofaker import Autodata
from datetime import datetime

@dataclass
class UserProfile:
    # Identity
    id: int
    username: str
    first_name: str
    last_name: str
    
    # Contact
    email: str
    phone_number: str
    
    # Location
    address: str
    city: str
    country: str
    zipcode: str
    
    # Work
    job: str
    company: str
    
    # Financial
    currency_name: str
    currency_code: str
    
    # Network
    ipv4: str
    ipv6: str
    hostname: str
    
    # Content
    text: str
    
    # Dates
    created_at: datetime

# Generate realistic profile
profile = Autodata.create(UserProfile, use_fake_data=True)

print("=== User Profile ===")
print(f"Name: {profile.first_name} {profile.last_name}")
print(f"Username: {profile.username}")
print(f"Email: {profile.email}")
print(f"Phone: {profile.phone_number}")
print(f"Job: {profile.job} at {profile.company}")
print(f"Location: {profile.city}, {profile.country} {profile.zipcode}")
print(f"Address: {profile.address}")
print(f"Currency: {profile.currency_name} ({profile.currency_code})")
print(f"Network: {profile.ipv4} / {profile.hostname}")
print(f"Bio: {profile.text[:100]}...")

# Sample output:
# === User Profile ===
# Name: John Smith
# Username: jsmith42
# Email: john.smith@example.com
# Phone: +1-555-123-4567
# Job: Software Engineer at TechCorp Inc.
# Location: New York, United States 10001
# Address: 123 Main Street, Apt 4B
# Currency: US Dollar (USD)
# Network: 192.168.1.100 / workstation-01.local
# Bio: Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit...

E-commerce Example

Realistic data for e-commerce testing:

ecommerce_fake.py 
from dataclasses import dataclass
from autofaker import Autodata
from typing import List

@dataclass
class Product:
    id: int
    name: str
    description: str
    price: float
    category: str

@dataclass
class Customer:
    id: int
    first_name: str
    last_name: str
    email: str
    phone_number: str
    address: str

@dataclass
class Order:
    id: int
    customer: Customer
    products: List[Product]
    total: float
    status: str

# Generate fake e-commerce data
customer = Autodata.create(Customer, use_fake_data=True)
products = Autodata.create_many(Product, 3, use_fake_data=True)

print("=== Customer ===")
print(f"{customer.first_name} {customer.last_name}")
print(f"Email: {customer.email}")
print(f"Address: {customer.address}")

print("\n=== Products ===")
for i, product in enumerate(products, 1):
    print(f"{i}. {product.name} - ${product.price:.2f}")
    print(f"   {product.description[:60]}...")

# Calculate total
total = sum(p.price for p in products)
print(f"\nOrder Total: ${total:.2f}")

DataFrame Examples

Sales Data Analysis

Generate DataFrames for data analysis testing:

sales_dataframe.py 
from dataclasses import dataclass
from autofaker import Autodata
from datetime import datetime
import pandas as pd

@dataclass
class SalesRecord:
    id: int
    product_name: str
    category: str
    quantity: int
    price: float
    customer_name: str
    sale_date: datetime
    region: str

# Generate sales data
sales_df = Autodata.create_pandas_dataframe(
    SalesRecord, 
    rows=100, 
    use_fake_data=True
)

print("=== Sales DataFrame Info ===")
print(f"Shape: {sales_df.shape}")
print(f"Columns: {list(sales_df.columns)}")
print("\n=== Sample Data ===")
print(sales_df.head())

print("\n=== Data Analysis ===")
# Calculate total revenue
sales_df['revenue'] = sales_df['quantity'] * sales_df['price']
total_revenue = sales_df['revenue'].sum()
print(f"Total Revenue: ${total_revenue:,.2f}")

# Top categories by revenue
category_revenue = sales_df.groupby('category')['revenue'].sum().sort_values(ascending=False)
print(f"\nTop Categories:")
print(category_revenue.head())

# Sales by region
region_sales = sales_df.groupby('region')['revenue'].sum()
print(f"\nSales by Region:")
print(region_sales)

Customer Analytics

Customer data for analytics and ML testing:

customer_analytics.py 
from dataclasses import dataclass
from autofaker import Autodata
from datetime import datetime

@dataclass
class CustomerData:
    customer_id: int
    first_name: str
    last_name: str
    email: str
    age: int
    city: str
    country: str
    signup_date: datetime
    last_purchase_date: datetime
    total_spent: float
    orders_count: int
    is_premium: bool

# Create customer dataset
customers_df = Autodata.create_pandas_dataframe(
    CustomerData, 
    rows=1000, 
    use_fake_data=True
)

print("=== Customer Analytics Dataset ===")
print(f"Total Customers: {len(customers_df)}")
print(f"\nDataset Info:")
print(customers_df.info())

print(f"\n=== Customer Insights ===")
# Age distribution
print(f"Average Age: {customers_df['age'].mean():.1f}")
print(f"Age Range: {customers_df['age'].min()} - {customers_df['age'].max()}")

# Spending analysis
print(f"\nSpending Analysis:")
print(f"Average Spent: ${customers_df['total_spent'].mean():.2f}")
print(f"Total Revenue: ${customers_df['total_spent'].sum():,.2f}")

# Premium customers
premium_customers = customers_df[customers_df['is_premium']].shape[0]
premium_percentage = (premium_customers / len(customers_df)) * 100
print(f"\nPremium Customers: {premium_customers} ({premium_percentage:.1f}%)")

# Top spending countries
country_spending = customers_df.groupby('country')['total_spent'].mean().sort_values(ascending=False)
print(f"\nTop Spending Countries:")
print(country_spending.head())

Advanced Examples

Enums and Literals

Work with complex type annotations:

enums_literals.py 
from dataclasses import dataclass
from autofaker import Autodata
from enum import Enum
from typing import Literal

class Priority(Enum):
    LOW = "low"
    MEDIUM = "medium"
    HIGH = "high"
    CRITICAL = "critical"

class Status(Enum):
    PENDING = "pending"
    IN_PROGRESS = "in_progress"
    COMPLETED = "completed"
    CANCELLED = "cancelled"

@dataclass
class Task:
    id: int
    title: str
    description: str
    priority: Priority
    status: Status
    category: Literal["bug", "feature", "improvement", "docs"]
    difficulty: Literal[1, 2, 3, 4, 5]

@dataclass
class Project:
    id: int
    name: str
    tasks: list[Task]
    lead: str

# Create tasks with enum and literal values
tasks = Autodata.create_many(Task, 5)

print("=== Generated Tasks ===")
for i, task in enumerate(tasks, 1):
    print(f"{i}. {task.title}")
    print(f"   Priority: {task.priority.value}")
    print(f"   Status: {task.status.value}")
    print(f"   Category: {task.category}")
    print(f"   Difficulty: {task.difficulty}/5")
    print()

# Create project with nested tasks
project = Autodata.create(Project)
print(f"=== Project: {project.name} ===")
print(f"Lead: {project.lead}")
print(f"Tasks: {len(project.tasks)}")

Complex Nested Structures

Handle deeply nested object hierarchies:

nested_structures.py 
from dataclasses import dataclass
from autofaker import Autodata
from typing import List, Optional
from datetime import datetime

@dataclass
class Address:
    street: str
    city: str
    state: str
    zipcode: str
    country: str

@dataclass
class Contact:
    phone: str
    email: str
    address: Address

@dataclass
class Department:
    id: int
    name: str
    budget: float

@dataclass
class Employee:
    id: int
    first_name: str
    last_name: str
    contact: Contact
    department: Department
    hire_date: datetime
    salary: float
    manager_id: Optional[int] = None

@dataclass
class Company:
    id: int
    name: str
    headquarters: Address
    employees: List[Employee]
    founded_year: int

# Create a complete company structure
company = Autodata.create(Company, use_fake_data=True)

print(f"=== {company.name} ===")
print(f"Founded: {company.founded_year}")
print(f"Headquarters: {company.headquarters.city}, {company.headquarters.state}")
print(f"Employees: {len(company.employees)}")

print(f"\n=== Employee Details ===")
for emp in company.employees[:3]:  # Show first 3 employees
    print(f"{emp.first_name} {emp.last_name}")
    print(f"  Department: {emp.department.name}")
    print(f"  Email: {emp.contact.email}")
    print(f"  Location: {emp.contact.address.city}")
    print(f"  Salary: ${emp.salary:,.2f}")
    print()

# Calculate company statistics
total_salary = sum(emp.salary for emp in company.employees)
avg_salary = total_salary / len(company.employees)
print(f"=== Company Statistics ===")
print(f"Total Payroll: ${total_salary:,.2f}")
print(f"Average Salary: ${avg_salary:,.2f}")

# Group by department
dept_counts = {}
for emp in company.employees:
    dept_name = emp.department.name
    dept_counts[dept_name] = dept_counts.get(dept_name, 0) + 1

print(f"\nEmployees by Department:")
for dept, count in dept_counts.items():
    print(f"  {dept}: {count}")

Testing Pattern Examples

Repository Testing

Test data access layers with realistic data:

repository_testing.py 
import unittest
from autofaker import autodata, fakedata
from dataclasses import dataclass
from typing import List, Optional

@dataclass
class User:
    id: int
    username: str
    email: str
    is_active: bool

class UserRepository:
    def __init__(self):
        self.users = []
    
    def save(self, user: User) -> User:
        if user.id == 0:
            user.id = len(self.users) + 1
        self.users.append(user)
        return user
    
    def find_by_id(self, user_id: int) -> Optional[User]:
        return next((u for u in self.users if u.id == user_id), None)
    
    def find_by_email(self, email: str) -> Optional[User]:
        return next((u for u in self.users if u.email == email), None)
    
    def find_active_users(self) -> List[User]:
        return [u for u in self.users if u.is_active]

class TestUserRepository(unittest.TestCase):
    
    def setUp(self):
        self.repo = UserRepository()
    
    @autodata()
    def test_save_user(self, user: User):
        # Test with anonymous data
        user.id = 0  # New user
        saved_user = self.repo.save(user)
        
        self.assertNotEqual(saved_user.id, 0)
        self.assertEqual(len(self.repo.users), 1)
    
    @fakedata()
    def test_find_by_email(self, user: User):
        # Test with realistic email
        self.repo.save(user)
        
        found_user = self.repo.find_by_email(user.email)
        self.assertIsNotNone(found_user)
        self.assertEqual(found_user.email, user.email)
    
    @autodata()
    def test_find_active_users(self, users: List[User]):
        # Set up test data
        users[0].is_active = True
        users[1].is_active = False
        users[2].is_active = True
        
        for user in users:
            self.repo.save(user)
        
        active_users = self.repo.find_active_users()
        self.assertEqual(len(active_users), 2)
        self.assertTrue(all(u.is_active for u in active_users))

if __name__ == '__main__':
    unittest.main()

Service Layer Testing

Test business logic with complex scenarios:

service_testing.py 
import unittest
from autofaker import autodata, fakedata
from dataclasses import dataclass
from datetime import datetime, timedelta

@dataclass
class Customer:
    id: int
    name: str
    email: str
    registration_date: datetime
    total_spent: float
    is_premium: bool

@dataclass
class Order:
    id: int
    customer_id: int
    amount: float
    order_date: datetime

class CustomerService:
    def __init__(self):
        self.customers = {}
        self.orders = {}
    
    def calculate_loyalty_points(self, customer: Customer) -> int:
        base_points = int(customer.total_spent / 10)
        premium_bonus = 1.5 if customer.is_premium else 1.0
        return int(base_points * premium_bonus)
    
    def is_eligible_for_upgrade(self, customer: Customer) -> bool:
        # Customer is eligible if they've spent >$500 and registered >30 days ago
        spent_threshold = customer.total_spent > 500
        time_threshold = (datetime.now() - customer.registration_date).days > 30
        return spent_threshold and time_threshold and not customer.is_premium
    
    def calculate_discount(self, customer: Customer, order_amount: float) -> float:
        if customer.is_premium:
            return order_amount * 0.15  # 15% discount
        elif customer.total_spent > 1000:
            return order_amount * 0.10  # 10% discount
        return 0.0

class TestCustomerService(unittest.TestCase):
    
    def setUp(self):
        self.service = CustomerService()
    
    @autodata()
    def test_loyalty_points_regular_customer(self, customer: Customer):
        customer.is_premium = False
        customer.total_spent = 100.0
        
        points = self.service.calculate_loyalty_points(customer)
        self.assertEqual(points, 10)  # 100/10 * 1.0
    
    @autodata()
    def test_loyalty_points_premium_customer(self, customer: Customer):
        customer.is_premium = True
        customer.total_spent = 100.0
        
        points = self.service.calculate_loyalty_points(customer)
        self.assertEqual(points, 15)  # 100/10 * 1.5
    
    @fakedata()
    def test_upgrade_eligibility(self, customer: Customer):
        # Set up conditions for upgrade eligibility
        customer.is_premium = False
        customer.total_spent = 600.0
        customer.registration_date = datetime.now() - timedelta(days=45)
        
        is_eligible = self.service.is_eligible_for_upgrade(customer)
        self.assertTrue(is_eligible)
        
        # Test edge cases
        customer.total_spent = 400.0  # Below threshold
        is_eligible = self.service.is_eligible_for_upgrade(customer)
        self.assertFalse(is_eligible)
    
    @autodata()
    def test_discount_calculation(self, customer: Customer):
        order_amount = 100.0
        
        # Test premium customer discount
        customer.is_premium = True
        discount = self.service.calculate_discount(customer, order_amount)
        self.assertEqual(discount, 15.0)
        
        # Test high-value customer discount
        customer.is_premium = False
        customer.total_spent = 1500.0
        discount = self.service.calculate_discount(customer, order_amount)
        self.assertEqual(discount, 10.0)
        
        # Test no discount
        customer.total_spent = 500.0
        discount = self.service.calculate_discount(customer, order_amount)
        self.assertEqual(discount, 0.0)

if __name__ == '__main__':
    unittest.main()
